testTitle: Life in the UK Test - Stuarts & Civil War
testDescription: Comprehensive test covering the Stuart dynasty, English Civil War, Commonwealth period, and the Restoration including key political and religious developments.

questions.stem: Who was the first Stuart king of England?
questions.explanation: James I became the first Stuart king of England in 1603 after Elizabeth I died without children. He was already James VI of Scotland.

questions.stem: The Gunpowder Plot took place in which year?
questions.explanation: The Gunpowder Plot occurred on November 5, 1605, when Guy Fawkes and other conspirators attempted to blow up Parliament.

questions.stem: Who was the leader of the Gunpowder Plot?
questions.explanation: Robert Catesby was the leader of the Gunpowder Plot. Guy Fawkes was caught with the gunpowder but was not the leader.

questions.stem: Guy Fawkes Night is celebrated on November 5th.
questions.explanation: True. Guy Fawkes Night (Bonfire Night) is celebrated on November 5th to commemorate the failure of the Gunpowder Plot.

questions.stem: What was the main cause of the English Civil War?

options.label: Disputes over money and power between King and Parliament

questions.explanation: The main cause was disputes between Charles I and Parliament over money, taxation, and the extent of royal power.

questions.stem: The English Civil War was fought between which two sides?
questions.explanation: The Civil War was fought between Royalists (Cavaliers) who supported the King and Parliamentarians (Roundheads) who supported Parliament.

questions.stem: Who led the Parliamentary forces in the Civil War?
questions.explanation: Oliver Cromwell became the leading Parliamentary general, especially famous for his New Model Army and cavalry tactics.

questions.stem: Charles I was executed in 1649.
questions.explanation: True. Charles I was executed on January 30, 1649, outside the Banqueting House in Whitehall, London.

questions.stem: What was the Commonwealth?
questions.explanation: The Commonwealth (1649-1660) was the period when England was a republic without a monarch, ruled by Parliament and later by Cromwell.

questions.stem: What was Oliver Cromwell's title when he ruled England?
questions.explanation: Oliver Cromwell ruled as Lord Protector from 1653 until his death in 1658, refusing the title of King.

questions.stem: Which activities did the Puritans ban during the Commonwealth?
questions.explanation: Puritans banned many forms of entertainment including theatre, elaborate Christmas celebrations, and dancing. They valued education and reading.

questions.stem: When was the monarchy restored?
questions.explanation: The monarchy was restored in 1660 when Charles II returned from exile, beginning the period known as the Restoration.

questions.stem: Charles II was known as the 'Merry Monarch.'
questions.explanation: True. Charles II was called the 'Merry Monarch' because he brought back entertainment, theatre, and a more relaxed atmosphere after the stern Puritan rule.

questions.stem: The Great Fire of London occurred in which year?
questions.explanation: The Great Fire of London occurred in September 1666, destroying much of medieval London including 13,200 houses and 87 churches.

questions.stem: Who designed many churches after the Great Fire of London?
questions.explanation: Sir Christopher Wren designed 51 new churches in London after the Great Fire, including the new St Paul's Cathedral.

questions.stem: The Great Plague of London occurred in 1665.
questions.explanation: True. The Great Plague of 1665 killed about 100,000 people in London, roughly a quarter of the population.

questions.stem: What was the Test Act?

options.label: A law excluding Catholics from public office

questions.explanation: The Test Act (1673) required people to take an oath denying Catholic beliefs before holding public office, effectively excluding Catholics.

questions.stem: James II was a Catholic king.
questions.explanation: True. James II was openly Catholic, which caused great concern among the Protestant English parliament and people.

questions.stem: What was the Glorious Revolution?
questions.explanation: The Glorious Revolution (1688) was the peaceful overthrow of James II and his replacement by William and Mary.

questions.stem: Who replaced James II after the Glorious Revolution?
questions.explanation: William of Orange and his wife Mary (James II's daughter) were invited to rule jointly after James II fled to France.

questions.stem: The Bill of Rights was passed in which year?
questions.explanation: The Bill of Rights was passed in 1689, establishing the rights of Parliament and limiting the power of the monarch.

questions.stem: The Bill of Rights established that:

options.label: The monarch could not suspend laws

questions.explanation: The Bill of Rights limited royal power, established Parliamentary control over taxes, and guaranteed regular elections. It ended absolute monarchy.

questions.stem: Habeas Corpus protects people from unlawful imprisonment.
questions.explanation: True. Habeas Corpus (established 1679) means 'you must have the body' and protects against unlawful detention without trial.

questions.stem: What was the New Model Army?
questions.explanation: The New Model Army was the professional army created by Parliament during the Civil War, known for its discipline and effectiveness.
